ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned great classroom communication and problem solving
How to manage my study time
Was able to learn about the fundamentals of deriving functions as well as pre-calculus/algebra refreshers that aided my understanding of calculus topics.
The ability to study and mange study habits.

in the psets there were lots of real-world context questions so i learnt a lot of maths which was applied to the real world. this course is solely calculus so youre expected to have a solid algebra basis before coming in

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The weaknesses is the concept understanding I think it can be improved by going over the material multiple times.
I feel this a very good introductory course for all first years you get a challenge thats manageable

John Hall is a great instructor and is very patient. He does a great job explaining concepts and answers questions in a helpful way. From what I've heard, math instructors at Yale are pretty hit-or-miss (more likely miss), so if you can, take this class with Professor Hall.

The strength is that it allowed me to learn calculus, and a deeper manner than just one semester Calc one course would do. The only con is that I have to take two semesters, including math, 111 but I think its very useful, since I want to learn calculus, and a deeper way

strengths: on canvas they copied sections of the textbook that we were required to know e.g formulas and example questions which helped so much when making the cheat sheets we could bring into the exam. professor hall was great at responding to answers in the class and genuinely wanted people to understand and feel like they could ask anything in class. practice exams were very helpful

weakness: pset questions were way harder than the midterm or final exams so it felt a bit discouraging not being able to do the psets when i did well on the exams.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have not taken calculus in high school or do not come from a strong math background, I would highly recommend taking 110. It is a nice transition to start taking math classes at Yale.
yes, I would recommend it to anybody who doesnt have a solid foundation of calc yet because this course really makes you know the why of math
no, unless you need it for major requirement. there are easier QR credits so dont do it just for the QR unless you have already done calculus before (i hadnt and found it quite a lot of work).
